description: A tall, aggressive reed that invades wetlands and beaches, outcompeting native plants and altering hydrology.
identificationTips: Seedhead: Dense, fluffy, purple-brown turning grey-white in winter.
lookAlikes: Native Phragmites (subsp. americanus) - usually smaller, reddish stems.
recommendedAction: Report immediately. Do not transport rhizomes or seeds.

description: A metallic green beetle that bores into ash trees, disrupting nutrient flow and killing the tree.
identificationTips: Larvae: Creamy white, segmented, found under bark.
Signs: D-shaped exit holes in bark, crown dieback.
recommendedAction: Don't move firewood. Report sightings on ash trees.

description: Small freshwater mussels that attach to hard surfaces, clogging pipes and outcompeting native mussels.
identificationTips: Pattern: Zig-zag dark stripes on light background.
recommendedAction: Clean, Drain, Dry your boat. Report if found in new lakes.

description: A biennial herb that dominates forest floors and interferes with soil fungi needed by trees.
identificationTips: First year: Rosette of kidney-shaped leaves.
Second year: Tall stalk (up to 1m) with white 4-petaled flowers.
Smell: Strong garlic odour when crushed.
recommendedAction: Pull by hand including root before seeds set.

description: A defoliating moth that strips leaves from hardwood trees like Oak and Maple.
identificationTips: Caterpillars: 5 pairs of blue spots, 6 pairs of red spots on back.
Egg masses: Tan, fuzzy patches on tree trunks.
Adult Male: Brown moth. Adult Female: White moth (flightless).
lookAlikes: Forest Tent Caterpillar (keyhole pattern, no red/blue spots).
recommendedAction: Scrape egg masses in winter. Burlap band trees in summer.
